{{Use dmy dates|date=June 2017}} {{Infobox recurring event | name = The United Nations Ocean Conference | native_name = | logo = | logo_caption = | image = The United Nations Ocean Conference Logo.jpg | imagesize = | caption = | date = <!--5–9 June 2017--> | begins = 5 June 2017 | ends = 9 June 2017 | prev = | next = | frequency = | location = [[Headquarters of the United Nations|UN HQ]], New York, United States | years_active = | first = <!--"founded=" also works--> | participants = | attendance = | genre = | budget = | patron = | organised = <!--"organized=" also works--> | website = [https://oceanconference.un.org/ oceanconference.un.org/] | footnotes = }} The '''2017 United Nations Ocean Conference''' was a United Nations conference that took place on June 5th-9th 2017 which sought to mobilize action for the [[Marine conservation|conservation]] and [[sustainability#Freshwater and oceans|sustainable]] use of the oceans, seas and marine resources.<ref name=about>{{cite web|title=The Ocean Conference {{!}} 5–9 June 2017|url=https://oceanconference.un.org/about|publisher=United Nations|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=ibtimes1>{{cite web|title=UN Ocean Conference 2017 Seeks To Avoid Climate Change Catastrophe|url=http://www.ibtimes.com/un-ocean-conference-2017-seeks-avoid-climate-change-catastrophe-2548332|work=International Business Times|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Erste UN-Ozeankonferenz hat begonnen|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/ausland/un-konferenz-ozeane-101.html|publisher=Tagesschau|accessdate=6 June 2017|language=de-DE}}</ref>
<!--Issues / its subject/s--> The [[Earth]]'s waters are said to be under [[Environmental issue|threat]] like never before, with [[Marine pollution|pollution]], [[overfishing]], and the [[Effects of global warming on oceans|effects of climate change]] severely damaging the health of our oceans. For instance as oceans are warming and [[ocean acidification|becoming more acidic]], [[biodiversity]] is becoming reduced and changing currents will cause more frequent storms and droughts.<ref name=cnbc1>{{cite web|last1=Frangoul|first1=Anmar|title=UN Secretary General Guterres says world's oceans are facing unprecedented threat|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2017/06/06/un-secretary-general-guterres-says-worlds-oceans-are-facing-unprecedented-threat.html|publisher=CNBC|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN chief calls for coordinated global action to solve ocean problems|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/06/c_136342371.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=acidi>{{cite web|title=West Coast states encourage worldwide fight against ocean acidification|url=http://www.governor.wa.gov/news-media/west-coast-states-encourage-worldwide-fight-against-ocean-acidification|publisher=Governor Inslee's Communications Office|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Save our Oceans – The Manila Times Online|url=http://www.manilatimes.net/save-our-oceans/330880/|work=Manila Times|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Klimawandel – Ozeankonferenz warnt vor Versauerung der Meere|url=http://www.deutschlandfunk.de/klimawandel-ozeankonferenz-warnt-vor-versauerung-der-meere.697.de.html?dram:article_id=387742|website=Deutschlandfunk|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=de-DE}}</ref> Every year around 8 million metric tons of [[plastic waste]] leak into the ocean and make it into the circular [[ocean current]]s. This causes contamination of sediments at [[Seabed|the sea-bottom]] and causes plastic waste to be embedded in the [[Aquatic ecosystem|aquatic]] [[food chain]].<ref>{{cite web|title=California models how to clean up, reduce, recycle plastic waste|url=http://www.sfchronicle.com/opinion/openforum/article/California-models-how-to-clean-up-reduce-11203281.php|work=San Francisco Chronicle|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref> It could lead to oceans containing more plastics than fish by 2050 if nothing is done.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Wearden|first1=Graeme|title=More plastic than fish in the sea by 2050, says Ellen MacArthur|url=https://www.theguardian.com/business/2016/jan/19/more-plastic-than-fish-in-the-sea-by-2050-warns-ellen-macarthur|work=The Guardian|accessdate=8 June 2017|date=19 January 2016}}</ref><ref name=wash1/><ref name=phys2>{{cite web|title=Plastic in rivers major source of ocean pollution: study|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-06-plastic-rivers-major-source-ocean.html|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref> Key habitats such as [[coral reefs]]<!--Coral bleaching--> are at risk and [[noise pollution]] are a threat to whales, dolphins, and other species.<ref>{{cite web|title=At the UN Ocean Conference, Recognizing an Unseen Pollutant: Noise|url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/08/at-the-un-ocean-conference-recognizing-an-unseen-pollutant-noise/|website=National Geographic Society (blogs)|accessdate=8 June 2017|date=8 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Recommendations for addressing Ocean Noise Pollution: A joint statement to the Oceans Conference|url=https://www.oceancare.org/wp-content/uploads/2017/05/UN_Unterwasserl%C3%A4rm_Joint-Statement_OceanConference_EN_2017.pdf|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Lind|first1=Fredrik|last2=Tanzer|first2=John|title=Make or break moment for the oceans|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/07/opinions/decline-of-the-oceans-opinion-lind-tanzer/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Furthermore almost 90 percent of fish stocks are overfished or fully [[Overexploitation#Fisheries|exploited]] which cost more than $80 billion a year in lost revenues.<ref name=factbox>{{cite web|title=FACTBOX-12 facts as World Oceans Day puts spotlight on climate change, pollution, overfishing|url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/world-oceans-fish-idUKL8N1J23IZ|agency=Reuters UK|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--The conference's intent--> UN Secretary-General [[António Guterres]] stated that decisive, coordinated global [[collective action|action]] can solve the problems created by [[Human]]ity.<ref name=cnbc1/> [[Peter Thomson (diplomat)|Peter Thomson]], President of the UN General Assembly, highlighted the conference's significance, saying "if we want a secure future for our species on this planet, we have to act now on the health of the ocean and on [[climate change]]".<ref name=cnbc1/><ref name=ibtimes1/> [[File:The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg|thumb|300px|Earth is often called the "blue planet" as oceans cover over 70 percent of the planet<ref name=factbox/> giving it a markedly blue appearance when seen from space<ref>{{cite book|last1=Jain|first1=Sharad K.|last2=Agarwal|first2=Pushpendra K.|last3=Singh|first3=Vijay P.|title=Hydrology and Water Resources of India|date=2007|publisher=Springer Science & Business Media|isbn=9781402051807|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ZKs1gBhJSWIC&pg=PA3|accessdate=8 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Kalman|first1=Bobbie|title=Earth's Coasts|date=2008|publisher=Crabtree Publishing Company|isbn=9780778732068|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=LuX0lulkRQ0C&pg=PA4|accessdate=8 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Leith|first1=James A.|last2=Price|first2=Raymond A.|last3=Spencer|first3=John Hedley|title=Planet Earth: Problems and Prospects|date=1995|publisher=McGill-Queen's Press – MQUP|isbn=9780773512924|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8eNPVbl1nJ0C&pg=PA172|accessdate=8 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|last1=Djavidnia|first1=Samy|last2=Ott|first2=Michael|last3=Seeyave|first3=Sophie|title=Oceans and Society: Blue Planet|date=2014|publisher=Cambridge Scholars Publishing|isbn=9781443861168|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=MMYxBwAAQBAJ&pg=PR11|accessdate=8 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> (here [[The Blue Marble|photographed]] by [[Apollo 17]] in 1972)]]<!--pertinence to topic at hand?-->
The conference sought to find ways and urge for the implementation of [[Sustainable Development Goal]] 14.<ref name=cnbc1/> Its theme is "Our oceans, our future: partnering for the implementation of Sustainable Development Goal 14".<ref>{{cite web|title=Ghana: UN Begins Ocean Conference to Stop the Sea Pollution|url=http://allafrica.com/stories/201706060879.html|website=Government of Ghana (Accra)|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref> It also asked governments, UN bodies, and civil society groups to make [[voluntary commitment]]s for action to improve the health of the oceans with over 1,000 commitments − such as on managing [[Marine protected area|protected areas]] − being made.<ref name=aljazeera1>{{cite web|title=UN chief warns oceans 'under threat as never before'|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/2017/06/chief-warns-oceans-threat-170605205005263.html|publisher=Al Jazeera|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN News – At Ocean Conference, UN agencies commit to cutting harmful fishing subsidies|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56920|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=en|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=xinhuanet1>{{cite web|title=UN marks World Oceans Day at Ocean Conference|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/09/c_136351595.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
==Participation== <!--General info--> Participants include heads of State and Government, [[civil society]] representatives, business people, actors, academics and scientists and ocean and marine life advocates from around{{How many|date=June 2017}} <!--almost 193-->200 countries.<ref name=unnews1/><ref name=aljazeera1/><ref>{{cite web|title=KUNA : Ocean Conf. kicks off activities, calls for accelerated action|url=http://www.kuna.net.kw/ArticleDetails.aspx?id=2615288&Language=en|website=kuna.net.kw|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=hindu1>{{cite web|title=City-based NGO to attend ocean meet|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-national/tp-kerala/city-based-ngo-to-attend-ocean-meet/article18717019.ece|work=The Hindu|accessdate=6 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Worland|first1=Justin|last2=Lull|first2=Julia|title=Marine Biologist Has a Message for Climate Change Deniers|url=http://time.com/4808959/climate-change-sylvia-earle-oceans-week/|work=Time|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Around 6,000 leaders gathered for the conference over the course of the week.<ref name=unn1>{{cite web|title=UN News – UN Ocean Conference wraps up with actions to restore ocean health, protect marine life|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56947|publisher=UN News Service Section|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=With focus on natural disasters, UN risk reduction forum opens in Mexico|url=http://indiablooms.com/ibns_new/world-details/F/11488/with-focus-on-natural-disasters-un-risk-reduction-forum-opens-in-mexico.html|publisher=Indiablooms|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=thenation1>{{cite web|title=Pakistan vows to back steps to improve world's oceans' health|url=http://nation.com.pk/snippets/11-Jun-2017/pakistan-vows-to-back-steps-to-improve-world-s-oceans-health|work=The Nation|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Organization--> The Governments of Fiji and Sweden had the co-hosting responsibilities of the Conference.<ref name=about/><ref name=ibtimes1/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Conduit|first1=Rox|title=UN Oceans Conference begins today|url=http://www.fbc.com.fj/fiji/51433/un-oceans-conference-begins-today|publisher=fbc.com.fj|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=PM: We’re Ready, Expect The Best This Week|url=https://fijisun.com.fj/2017/06/05/pm-were-ready-expect-the-best-this-week/|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Prime Minister of Sri Lanka addresses UN ocean conference|url=http://www.lankabusinessonline.com/prime-minister-of-sri-lanka-addresses-un-ocean-conference/|publisher=Lanka Business Online|accessdate=7 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=To save our oceans|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=403986|work=Fiji Times|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> <!--the Conference was originally scheduled to take place in Fiji. But Cyclone Winston caused heavy damage to the island in 2016 and the Conference was moved to New York-->
<!--Dialoges--> 7 partnership dialogues with a rich state-developed state theme were co-chaired by Australia-Kenya, Iceland-Peru, Canada-Senegal, Estonia-Grenada, Italy-Palau, Monaco-Mozambique and Norway-Indonesia.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Sood|first1=Vrinda|title=Will the US Play a Role at the UN Oceans Forum This June?|url=https://thewire.in/137660/un-oceans-forum/|work=The Wire|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=14 Governments Appointed Co-Chairs of Ocean Dialogues |url=http://sdg.iisd.org/news/14-governments-appointed-co-chairs-of-ocean-dialogues/|publisher=IISD's SDG Knowledge Hub|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Small island countries--> Ministers from small [[island state]]s such as Palau, Fiji and Tuvalu<!--[[Small Island Developing States]]--> pleaded for help as for them the issue is existential not just on the long-term.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Roth|first1=Richard|title=At first UN Ocean Conference, island nations plead for help|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2017/06/07/world/small-island-nations-un-ocean-conference/index.html|publisher=CNN|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kommentar: Wieviel Dummheit verträgt ein Ozean?|url=https://www.tagesschau.de/kommentar/weltmeere-101.html|publisher=Tagesschau|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=de-DE}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Simmons|first1=Ann M.|title=One looming consequence of climate change: Small island nations will cease to exist|url=http://www.latimes.com/world/global-development/la-fg-global-hugh-sealy-qa-snap-20161115-story.html|work=Los Angeles Times|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=15 November 2016}}</ref>
===Outcomes=== <!--Intro to commitments--> Over 1,300 voluntary commitments have been made which UN Under-Secretary-General for Economic and Social Affairs [[Wu Hongbo]] called "truly impressive" and stated that they now comprise "an ocean solution registry" via the public online platform<!--https://oceanconference.un.org/commitments/-->.<ref name=unn1/><ref name=fijisun1/> 44 percent of the commitments came from governments, 19 percent from NGOs, 9 percent from UN entities and 6 percent from the private sector.<ref>{{cite web|title=Vital action|url=http://www.fijitimes.com/story.aspx?id=404147|work=Fiji Times|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
<!--Plastics--> Delegates from China, Thailand, Indonesia and the Philippines pledged to work to keep plastics out of the seas.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harrabin|first1=Roger|title=Asian nations make plastic oceans promise|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/science-environment-40195664|publisher=BBC News|accessdate=8 June 2017|date=8 June 2017}}</ref> The Maldives announced a phase out of its non-[[biodegradable plastic]] and Austria pledged to reduce the number of [[plastic bag]]s<!--[[Phase-out of lightweight plastic bags]]--> used per person to 25 a year by 2019.<ref name=sky1>{{cite web|title=Experts tell Trump: 'Don't forget the oceans'|url=http://news.sky.com/story/environment-experts-tell-donald-trump-dont-forget-the-oceans-10907932|publisher=Sky News|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Marine protected areas--> Several nations announced plans for new marine protected areas. China plans to establish 10 to 20 "demonstration zones"<!--clarification needed?--> by 2020 and introduced a regulation which requires that 35 percent of [[Coastline of China|the country's shoreline]] should be natural by 2020.<ref>{{cite web|title=China supports marine-friendly 'blue economy'|url=http://www.ecns.cn/2017/06-08/260648.shtml|website=ecns.cn|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref><!--coastline=MPA-related?--> Gabon announced that it will create one of Africa's largest marine protected areas with around 53,000 square kilometres of ocean when combined with its existing zones.<ref>{{cite web|title=Gabon to create one of Africa's largest marine protected areas|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/voices/campaigns/elephant-campaign/gabon-to-create-one-of-africa-s-largest-marine-protected-areas-a7774271.html|work=The Independent|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=5 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=wash1/><ref name=chicagotribune1>{{cite web|last1=Lederer|first1=Edith M.|title=More plastic than fish? Oceans 'under threat as never before,' warns UN chief|url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/news/nationworld/science/ct-un-conference-on-oceans-20170605-story.html|work=Chicago Tribune|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> New Zealand affirmed the government's commitment to establishing the [[Kermadec_Islands#Conservation|Kermadec/Rangitahua Ocean Sanctuary]], which − with 620,000 square kilometres − would be one of the world's largest fully protected areas.<ref>{{cite web|title=NZ commits to protecting and conserving ocean|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/332712/nz-commits-to-protecting-and-conserving-ocean|publisher=Radio New Zealand|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en-nz|date=10 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Govt urged to walk the talk on dolphins, oceans|url=http://www.radionz.co.nz/news/national/332755/govt-urged-to-walk-the-talk-on-dolphins-oceans|publisher=Radio New Zealand|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en-nz|date=11 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Kermadec ocean sanctuary named – but no compensation|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/nz/news/article.cfm?c_id=1&objectid=11679590|work=The New Zealand Herald|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en-NZ}}</ref> Pakistan also announced its first marine protected area.<ref>{{cite web|title=Is the tide turning for oceans?|url=http://news.trust.org/item/20170607102543-lejsp/|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Financial commitments--> The US-based international wildlife organisation [[Wildlife Conservation Society]] created the MPA Fund in 2016 as well as the blue moon fund for a combined $15 million commitment which aims to create 3.7 million square kilometers of new marine protected areas with The Tiffany & Co. Foundation adding a $1 million grant toward this fund in the week of the conference.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Samper|first1=Cristián|title=It Will Take the World Community to Save the World's Ocean|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/it-will-take-the-world-community-to-save-the-worlds_us_593b19fce4b094fa859f185b|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=9 June 2017}}</ref> Germany's [[Federal Ministry for the Environment, Nature Conservation, Building and Nuclear Safety|Federal Minister for the Environment, Nature Conservation and Nuclear Safety]] [[Barbara Hendricks (politician)|Barbara Hendricks]] also pledged to allocate €670 million for marine conservation projects and made 11 voluntary commitments.<ref>{{cite web|title=Hendricks wirbt bei UNO für internationale Anstrengungen beim Meeresschutz|url=http://www.stern.de/news/hendricks-wirbt-bei-uno-fuer-internationale-anstrengungen-beim-meeresschutz-7487536.html|work=Stern|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=de-DE|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Hendricks wirbt bei UNO für internationale Anstrengungen beim Meeresschutz|url=http://www.wochenblatt.de/nachrichten/welt/Hendricks-wirbt-bei-UNO-fuer-internationale-Anstrengungen-beim-Meeresschutz;art29,448734|publisher=Wochenblatt|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=de-de}}</ref>
<!--Notable statements (/..?)--> Deputy Director-General of the State Oceanic Administrations Lin Shanqing of China − the world's [[Fishing industry in China|main fish producer and exporter]]<ref name=factbox/> − stated that the country would be "willing, based on its own development experience, to work actively for the establishment in the area of the ocean of an open, inclusive, concrete, pragmatic, mutually beneficial and win-win blue partnership with other countries and international organizations".<ref>{{cite web|title=China calls for enhancing equality, mutual trust in global ocean governance|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/08/c_136348429.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref><!--very notable as China is one of the major polluter & relevant producer etc-->
<!--United call for action--> The conference ended with the adoption by consensus of a 14-point Call for Action by the 193 UN member states in which they affirmed their "strong commitment to conserve and sustainably use our oceans, seas and marine resources tor sustainable development".<ref name=spiegel1>{{cite web|title=Meereskonferenz: Uno-Mitgliedstaaten verabreden Schutz der Ozeane|url=http://www.spiegel.de/wissenschaft/natur/meereskonferenz-uno-mitgliedstaaten-verabreden-schutz-der-ozeane-a-1151515.html|work=Der Spiegel|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=unn1/><ref name=xin1>{{cite web|title=Five-day UN Ocean Conference concludes with Call to Action|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/10/c_136355019.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=indianexpress1>{{cite web|title=193 UN member nations urge action to protect oceans, US backs call|url=http://indianexpress.com/article/world/193-un-member-nations-urge-action-to-protect-oceans-us-backs-call-4697093/|work=The Indian Express|accessdate=10 June 2017|date=10 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=thenation1/><ref name=unn1/> With this call, the Ocean Conference also sought to [[Consciousness raising|raise global awareness]] of ocean problems.<ref name=fijisun1/>
===Private sector=== <!--Intro / intent--> On 9 June an official side event of the United Nations Ocean Conference for addressing ways by which the [[private sector]] provides practical solutions to address the problems such as by improving energy efficiency, [[waste management]]<ref>{{cite web|title=UN-Ozeankonferenz: Ohne Blau kein Grün auf unserer Erde – heute-Nachrichten|url=http://www.heute.de/un-ozeankonferenz-ohne-blau-kein-gruen-auf-unserer-erde-47318554.html|publisher=heute (ZDF)|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=de}}</ref> and introducing market-based tools to shift investment, subsidy and production.<ref>{{cite web|title=UN Oceans Conference side-event showcases private sector solutions to worsening climate impacts – ICC – International Chamber of Commerce|url=https://iccwbo.org/media-wall/news-speeches/un-oceans-conference-side-event-showcases-private-sector-solutions-worsening-climate-impacts/|publisher=ICC – International Chamber of Commerce|accessdate=7 June 2017|date=7 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Arrangements--> Nine of the world's biggest [[Fishing industry|fishing companies]] from Asia, Europe and the US have signed up for The Seafood Business for Ocean Stewardship (SeaBOS) initiative, supported by the [[Stockholm Resilience Centre]], aiming to end [[Sustainable business|unsustainable practices]].<ref>{{cite web|last1=Harvey|first1=Fiona|title=Nine of world's biggest fishing firms sign up to protect oceans|url=https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2017/jun/09/nine-of-worlds-biggest-fishing-firms-sign-up-to-protect-oceans|work=The Guardian|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=9 June 2017}}</ref>
===Research and technology projects=== {{See also|Environmental technology}} <!--Technology, platforms, etc--> At the conference Indonesia published its [[Vessel monitoring system]] (VMS) publicly revealing the location and activity of its commercial fishing boats on the [[Global Fishing Watch]] public mapping platform.<ref name=phys1>{{cite web|title=Indonesia makes its fishing fleet visible to the world through Global Fishing Watch|url=https://phys.org/news/2017-06-indonesia-fishing-fleet-visible-world.html|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref> [[Brian Sullivan (Google)|Brian Sullivan]] states that the platform is can easily incorporate additional data sources which may allow "mov[ing] from raw data to quickly producing dynamic visualizations and reporting that promote scientific discovery and support policies for better [[Fisheries management|fishery management]]".<ref name=phys1/>
<!--Science, research, etc--> Irina Bokova of [[UNESCO]] notes that "we cannot manage what we cannot measure, and no single country is able to measure the myriad changes taking place in the ocean", and asks for more [[Oceanography|maritime research]] and the [[knowledge sharing|sharing of knowledge]] to craft common [[evidence-based policy|science-based policies]].<ref name=xinhuanet1/><br/> Peru co-chaired the "Partnership Dialogue 6 – Increasing scientific knowledge, and developing research capacity<!--[[Research development]]--> and [[Technology transfer|transfer]] of [[marine technology]]" with Iceland.<ref name=andina1/><br/> On 7 June researchers at the Dutch [[The Ocean Cleanup]] foundation published a study according to which rivers − such as the [[Yangtze]] − carry an around 1.15–2.41 million tonnes of plastic into the sea every year.<ref name=phys2/><ref>{{cite web|title=Plastic in rivers major source of ocean pollution: study|url=http://nation.com.pk/snippets/09-Jun-2017/plastic-in-rivers-major-source-of-ocean-pollution-study|work=The Nation|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Most ocean plastic comes from Asian rivers: study|url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/news/2017/06/09/world/science-health-world/ocean-plastic-comes-asian-rivers-study/|work=Japan Times|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Plastics remain the major source of ocean pollution – Kuwait Times|url=http://news.kuwaittimes.net/website/plastics-remain-major-source-ocean-pollution/|work=Kuwait Times|accessdate=11 June 2017|date=11 June 2017}}</ref>
==Obstacles to implementation==<!-- of SDG 14--> {{See also|Social responsibility|State responsibility}} <!--National "short-term territorial[, economic, ...] and resource interests"--> [[File:North Pacific Subtropical Convergence Zone.jpg|thumb|North Pacific Subtropical Convergence Zone − the location of the [[Great Pacific Garbage Patch]]]] [[File:Plastic Ocean (4408273247).jpg|thumb|200px|An example of sea pollution which the conference sought to avert.]] UN Secretary-General [[António Guterres]] warned that unless nations overcome short-term territorial and resource interests the state of the oceans will continue to deteriorate. He also names "the artificial [[dichotomy]]" between jobs and healthy oceans as one of the main challenges and asks for strong political [[leadership]], new partnerships and concrete steps.<ref name=unnews1>{{cite web|title=UN Ocean Conference opens with calls for united action to reverse human damage|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=56905|publisher=UN News Centre|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Conserving our oceans and using them sustainably is preserving life itself|url=http://www.news.com.au/technology/environment/conservation/united-nations-secretary-general-implores-countries-to-prevent-global-catastrophe-through-ocean-conservation/news-story/67aa0b2e7705d2bacbb9c281ffb9151e|website=NewsComAu|accessdate=6 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Mehr Plastik als Plankton|url=http://www.tagesspiegel.de/weltspiegel/gigantische-umweltprobleme-der-ozeane-mehr-plastik-als-plankton/19898494.html|work=Der Tagesspiegel|accessdate=6 June 2017|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN calls on world to save our oceans|url=http://www.euronews.com/2017/06/05/un-calls-on-world-to-save-our-oceans|website=euronews|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=5 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=UN Ocean meet calls for united action|url=http://www.thehindu.com/todays-paper/tp-in-school/un-ocean-meet-calls-for-united-action/article18733705.ece|work=The Hindu|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=en}}</ref><ref name=wash1>{{cite web|title=UN chief warns oceans are 'under threat as never before'|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/un-chief-warns-oceans-are-under-threat-as-never-before/2017/06/05/7c849742-4a15-11e7-987c-42ab5745db2e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
Deputy Secretary-General of the United Nations [[Amina J. Mohammed|Amina J Mohammed]] warns about the harm of overlooking the climate concerns in turn for perceived "national gain", claiming that "a [[moral obligation]] to the world which [one] live[s] on" exists.<ref name=townhall1>{{cite web|last1=Timmis|first1=Anna|title=UN Officials React to Trump's Paris Decision at Ocean Conference|url=https://townhall.com/tipsheet/annatimmis/2017/06/07/officials-reaction-to-trump-at-ocean-conference-n2337298|publisher=Townhall|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
<!--India--> India, attended indirectly via two non-governmental organisations<ref name=hindu1/> until 9 June when Minister of State for External Affairs [[M J Akbar]] told the conference that the negative impact of overfishing, habitat destruction, pollution and climate change are becoming increasingly clear and that the time for action would be "already long overdue".<ref>{{cite web|title=Don't turn seas into areas of conflict, says MJ Akbar at United Nations Ocean Conference|url=http://www.firstpost.com/india/dont-turn-seas-into-areas-of-conflict-says-mj-akbar-at-united-nations-ocean-conference-3534035.html|publisher=Firstpost|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Do Not Turn Seas into Areas of Conflict: MJ Akbar|url=http://www.ndtv.com/india-news/do-not-turn-seas-into-areas-of-conflict-mj-akbar-1709938|publisher=NDTV|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--US--> Bolivia's President [[Evo Morales]] told the conference that, one of the world's main polluters, the [[government of the United States|United States]] denied science, turned its backs on multilateralism, and attempted to deny a future to upcoming generations by its national government deciding to [[United States withdrawal from the Paris Agreement|leave the Paris agreement]], making "it the main threat to Mother Earth and life itself".<ref name=aljazeera1/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Papenfuss|first1=Mary|title=U.S. Lashed As 'Main Threat' To Environment at UN Ocean Conference|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/us-main-environmental-threat-united-nations_us_593618e4e4b0099e7faeaac2|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=wash1/><ref name=chicagotribune1/><ref name=townhall1/> [[Albert II, Prince of Monaco]] called Trump's withdrawal "catastrophic" and the reaction from US mayors, governors and many in the corporate world as "wonderful".<ref>{{cite web|title=Monaco's ruler: Trump should listen to scientists on climate|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/europe/monacos-ruler-trump-should-listen-to-scientists-on-climate/2017/06/07/3eeca946-4bce-11e7-987c-42ab5745db2e_story.html|work=The Washington Post|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> On 30 May Sweden's deputy prime minister [[Isabella Lövin]] stated that the United States is resisting plans to highlight how climate change is disrupting life in the oceans at the conference, that the US has negatively affected preparations and that "the decline of the oceans is really a threat to the entire planet" with a "need to start working together".<ref name=reuters1>{{cite web|title=INTERVIEW-US resists plan to link climate change, ocean health-UN co-chair|url=http://news.trust.org/item/20170530150853-6bg97|publisher=Thomson Reuters Foundation|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=U.S. resists plan to link climate change, ocean health: U.N. co-chair|url=http://www.businessinsider.com/r-us-resists-plan-to-link-climate-change-ocean-health-un-co-chair-2017-5?IR=T|publisher=Business Insider|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> Lovin also makes note of difficulties to engage with Washington in the conference, partly because key posts at the [[National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration]] remain unfilled since the end of the Obama administration.<ref name=reuters1/>
<!--Subsidies--> UNCTAD Secretary-General [[Mukhisa Kituyi]] states that [[subsidies]] from wealthy governments encourage overfishing, overcapacity and may contribute to [[Illegal, unreported and unregulated fishing|illegal and unregulated fishing]], creating [[food insecurity]], unemployment and poverty for people relying mainly on fish as their primary source of nourishment or livelihood.<ref>{{cite web|title=UNCTAD and other global influencers gather to discuss eliminating harmful fisheries subsidies at UN Ocean Conference|url=http://unctad.org/en/pages/newsdetails.aspx?OriginalVersionID=1494|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=en-us}}</ref>
==Impact and progress==<!--/continuation/...--> <!--Requires not just UN--> [[Marine biologist]] Ayana Elizabeth Johnson notes that the UN's work alone is not nearly enough and that for a solution to this existential crisis of the health of our global environment, strong and inspired leadership at all levels – from mayors, to governors, CEOs, scientists, artists and presidents is needed.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Johnson|first1=Ayana Elizabeth|title=Climate, Oceans, the United Nations, and What's Next|url=http://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/02/climate-oceans-the-united-nations-and-whats-next/|website=National Geographic Society (blogs)|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=2 June 2017}}</ref>
<!--Goals and how much of it has been achieved etc--> In 2010 the international community agreed to protect 10% of the ocean by 2020 in the [[Convention on Biological Diversity]]'s Strategic Plan for Biodiversity 2011–2020 and Sustainable Development Goal 14.<ref>{{cite web|title=Marine Protected Areas and climate change|url=https://portals.iucn.org/library/sites/library/files/documents/2016-067.pdf|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Global marine protected are a target of 10% to be achieved by 2020|url=https://www.cbd.int/doc/press/2017/pr-2017-06-05-mpa-pub-en.pdf|accessdate=10 June 2017}}</ref> However as of June 2017 less than 3% of the ocean are under some form of protection.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Mittler|first1=Daniel|title=Time for ocean action – for us, our climate and diversity on earth|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/time-for-ocean-action-for-us-our-climate-and-diversity_us_59382a87e4b0b65670e566c6|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=7 June 2017}}</ref> Pledges made during the conference would add around an additional 4.4 percent of protected marine areas,<ref name=indianexpress1/> increasing the protected total to around 7.4% of the ocean.
<!--Organizers' résumé--> Peter Thomson called the conference was a success, stating that he was "satisfied with [its] results", that the conference "held at a very critical time" has "turned the tide on [[marine pollution]]". He says that "we are now working around the world to restore a relationship of balance and respect towards the ocean".<ref name=unn1/><ref name=xin1/>
<!--Procedure from there--> [[Elizabeth Wilson]], director of international conservation at [[Pew Charitable Trusts]] thinks that this meeting "will be followed by a whole series of other meetings that we hope will be impacted in a positive way".<ref>{{cite web|title='We cannot afford to fail': Pacific leaders appeal for action on World Oceans Day|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2017-06-08/pacific-leaders-set-the-agenda-for-world-oceans-day/8597994|publisher=ABC News|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=en-AU|date=8 June 2017}}</ref>
The next conference is scheduled for 2020.<ref name=portugal1/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Hostert|first1=Alexandra|title=The Ocean Conference – Absehbar oder enttäuschend?|url=http://www1.wdr.de/mediathek/audio/wdr5/wdr5-leonardo-top-themen/audio-the-ocean-conference---absehbar-oder-enttaeuschend-100.html|publisher=WDR|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=de|date=9 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=fijisun1>{{cite web|title=Ocean Conference Strikes More Than 1k Commitments {{!}} Fiji Sun|url=https://fijisun.com.fj/2017/06/11/ocean-conference-strikes-more-than-1k-commitments/|accessdate=11 June 2017}}</ref> Portugal's Minister for the Seas, [[Ana Paula Vitorino]] stated that [[Lisbon]] would like to host the next event in 2020.<ref name=portugal1>{{cite web|title=Portugal wants next UN Ocean Conference|url=http://www.theportugalnews.com/news/portugal-wants-next-un-ocean-conference/42165|accessdate=9 June 2017}}</ref> Kenya's Foreign Affairs Cabinet Secretary [[Amina Mohamed]] also offered for Keyna to host the next event.<ref name=fijisun1/><ref>{{cite web|title=Kenya submits AG Muigai as candidate for UN sea law organ|url=http://www.the-star.co.ke/news/2017/06/09/kenya-submits-ag-muigai-as-candidate-for-un-sea-law-organ_c1577546|publisher=The Star, Kenya|accessdate=11 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
==Culture and society== {{See also|Sea in culture|Active citizenship}} <!--Global awareness days--> The event coincided with the [[World Oceans Day]] on 8 June and started with the [[World Environment Day]] on 5 June.<ref name=about/><ref>{{cite web|last1=Chhotray|first1=Shilpi|title=Kicking Off The United Nations Ocean Conference|url=https://voices.nationalgeographic.com/2017/06/05/kicking-off-the-united-nations-ocean-conference/|website=National Geographic Society (blogs)|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=5 June 2017}}</ref><ref name=andina1>{{cite web|title=Production Ministry leads Peru delegation at UN Ocean Conference|url=http://www.andina.com.pe/ingles/noticia-production-ministry-leads-peru-delegation-at-un-ocean-conference-669635.aspx|publisher=andina.com.pe|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=es}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Local Chapter Headed to Ocean Conference at U.N. Headquarters – Times of San Diego|url=http://timesofsandiego.com/politics/2017/06/03/local-chapter-headed-to-ocean-conference-at-u-n-headquarters/|publisher=Times of San Diego|accessdate=7 June 2017|date=3 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Pollution Slowly Killing Planet's Ocean|url=https://www.newdelhitimes.com/pollution-slowly-killing-planets-ocean-123/|work=New Delhi Times|accessdate=9 June 2017|date=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Besheer|first1=Margaret|title=Pollution Slowly Killing Planet's Ocean|url=https://www.voanews.com/a/pollution-slowly-killing-earth-ocean/3888534.html|publisher=VOA|accessdate=9 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
<!--Side-events--> On 4 June the World Ocean Festival took place at New York City's [[Governors Island]]. The festival was hosted by the [[City of New York]], organized by the Global Brain Foundation and was free and open to the public.<ref>{{cite web|title=UN announces first-ever World Ocean Festival|url=https://www.un.org/sustainabledevelopment/blog/2017/04/un-announces-first-ever-world-ocean-festival/|website=United Nations Sustainable Development|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=11 April 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Thomson To Welcome RFMF Band|url=https://fijisun.com.fj/2017/06/05/thomson-to-welcome-rfmf-band/|accessdate=6 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|last1=Nicholls|first1=Sebastian|title=Celebrating a Living Ocean of Wonder|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/celebrating-a-living-ocean-of-wonder_us_590951dde4b084f59b49fe0c|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=3 May 2017}}</ref>
<!--Planned cultural events--> China announced a new international sailing competition and Noahs Sailing Club press officer Rebecca Wang stated that "sailing allows for a better appreciation of the ocean and the natural environment. Many wealthy Chinese think of luxury yachts when they think of [[List of water sports|maritime sport]]s, and we're trying to foster a maritime culture that's more attuned to the environment".<ref>{{cite web|title=Chinese club unveils open-ocean yacht race plan|url=http://www.scmp.com/news/china/society/article/2097397/chinese-club-unveils-open-ocean-yacht-race-plan-un-conference|work=South China Morning Post|accessdate=10 June 2017|language=en}}</ref>
<!--Cyber/social media campaign / citizens--> Users of [[social media]] worldwide use the [[hashtag]] #SaveOurOcean for discussion, information and media related to the conference and its goals.<ref>{{cite web|last1=Neill|first1=Peter|title=United Nations Ocean Conference: Our Ocean, Our Future|url=http://www.huffingtonpost.com/entry/united-nations-ocean-conference-our-ocean-our-future_us_591b2338e4b03e1c81b0091f|work=The Huffington Post|accessdate=6 June 2017|date=16 May 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Committed to the Ocean: The First United Nations Ocean Conference|url=https://global.nature.org/content/committed-to-the-ocean-the-first-united-nations-ocean-conference|publisher=Nature Conservancy Global Solutions|accessdate=7 June 2017|language=en}}</ref> The #CleanSeas [[Political campaign|cyber campaign]] calls on governments, industry and citizens to end excessive, wasteful usage of single-use plastic and eliminate [[microplastics]] [[Ingredients of cosmetics|in cosmetics]] with its petition getting signed by more than 1 million people.<ref>{{cite web|title=Over 1 million people demand global ban on single-use plastic at UN Ocean Conference|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/07/c_136345280.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=7 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Plastic is not fantastic: time to curb its use|url=https://www.irishtimes.com/news/environment/plastic-is-not-fantastic-time-to-curb-its-use-1.3087969|work=The Irish Times|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=Ozeane – Heimat für Korallen und Plastikmüll|url=http://www.dw.com/de/ozeane-heimat-f%C3%BCr-korallen-und-plastikm%C3%BCll/a-37765625|publisher=Deutsche Welle|accessdate=8 June 2017|language=de}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|title=British billionaire delivers 1 mln signatures urging governments to protect ocean|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2017-06/09/c_136351119.htm|agency=Xinhua News Agency|accessdate=8 June 2017}}</ref>
